channel.title: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3
channel.description: If anyone has the code, Please gimme cuz i need it. :cool:

item.title: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

if you are to implement it from scratch, seems like you might want to,
Solution:

  1. Open the audio file and grab the value at each time [so you should have two arrays, one have time and other the corresponding value of the signal]
  2. now what you need to do is reduce the signal values (call it amplitude), lets say my signal has the following amplitude values [50,40,30,20,10]
  3. since it’s fade out it should be exponentially fading, that means your amplitude should decrease by an exponential factor, so lets say i want to reduce it by 0.5 every time, so my new signal amplitude would look like this [50*(0.5)^1, 40*(0.5)^2, 30*(0.5)^3, 20*(0.5)^4, 10*(0.5)^5] = [25, 10, 3.75, 1.25, 0.3125]

**note since the audio would have more points it would be smooth transition, now i randomly chose 0.5, you can pick any value you like.

at the end the exponential factor causes your audio signal amplitude value to be like this,thus it looks as if the sound is fading out!

how fast you want it to fade depends on the exponential factor,which i choose as 0.5 here

Read full topic
item.source: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3

item.title: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You just need to be playing the MP3 on its own channel, and then you can set that channel’s volume. Most half decent audio libraries allow channel fade-in/fade-out functionally, so you may not need to do anything with volume.

Read full topic

just use the volume control, if you are worried about it messing with the users settings get the current volume setting fade the song, stop the song, then return to the original volume setting.

item.title: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

RiiPiiNFtW:

Yea I found that. But thats for MIDI audio files, and that one uses volume control to fade it away.

You know how crazy you would have to go to have it edit the audio file live? Changing the volume control would be your most logical, and simple solution. I would suggest just writing your own library for playing mp3 files. You’ll understand a lot more about it that way.

Read full topic

item.title: Fading Out music in Java for .mp3
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[code]
public void fadeOut() {
double volume = 0.6;

            for (;;) {
                    if (((volume - 0.05) < 0) || !setVolume(volume)) {
                            break;
                    }
                    try {
                            Thread.sleep(150);
                    } catch (Exception exception) {
                    }
                    volume -= 0.025;
            }
            if (synthesizer != null) {
                    synthesizer.close();
                    synthesizer = null;
            }
            if (sequencer != null) {
                    if (sequencer.isOpen()) {
                            sequencer.stop();
                    }
                    sequencer.close();
            }
    }[/code]

Credits to Primadude on R-S

Not sure if this is EXACTLY what you’re looking for, but I ripped that one method.
By the way, google is a good tool -.-

Read full topic
